description: '''Toytown pop''' is a [[microgenre]] of [[pop music]] which emerged in the 1960s. It was most popular in the [[UK singles chart|British singles charts]] between 1967 and 1974. At the height of psychedelia, an abundance of what music journalist [[Rob Chapman (journalist)|Rob Chapman]] cites as "[[Nursery rhyme|nursery-rhyme]] pop songs" appeared. The style is marked by the influence of [[LSD]] and psychedelia, as well as the work of authors such as [[Lewis Carroll]], [[Edward Lear]], [[C. S. Lewis]], [[Hilaire Belloc|J. M. Barrie]], [[Hilaire Belloc]], [[Beatrix Potter]], [[Charles Kingsley|Charles Kingley]], and [[Enid Blyton]].    {{Psychedelic sidebar|Arts}}The genre contrasted with American artists who made music in response to the [[Vietnam War]], which was not broadly the case in the United Kingdom.
